awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SHF: Small: Integrating Synthesis and Optimization in Satisfiability Modulo Theories
awd_abstract_narration:
The ever-increasing demand for optimized large-scale computing systems puts pressure on attaining significant improvements in automated design optimization and synthesis tools. This project aims to overcome the limitations of prior approaches through a tighter integration of optimization and synthesis algorithms leveraging advances in modern automated reasoning systems.  The project demonstrates the power of Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT)-based synthesis combined with emerging research in Optimization Modulo Theories (OMT). 

The project explores advances in both theory and practice, with research demonstrations integrated into CVC4, the only SMT solver today providing synthesis features.  In particular, CVC4 is being extended with optimization capabilities, making it the first automated reasoning tool capable of performing synthesis and optimization together. The resulting extensible framework enables system design for emerging technologies which often require reasoning over non Boolean (and mixed) primitives. The extensibility and generality of the approach charts a new direction of research at the intersection of synthesis and optimization, leads towards more scalable and complex system design, and allows optimization over a broader class of objectives including security and safety.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the realm of computing, the quest for systems that are faster, more efficient, and capable of handling more complex tasks has led to groundbreaking research and development efforts. This project, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), enhanced how computing systems are designed and optimized. At the heart of the project was the integration of advanced optimization and synthesis algorithms, using modern automated reasoning systems. This effort pushed the boundaries of computing capabilities, particularly through the innovative combination of Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT) and Optimization Modulo Theories (OMT).  If neural networks are the "thinking fast" of computer reasoning, these theories are the careful, logical, and deductive reasoning that must work hand-in-hand with that approach.

This was achieved through enhancements to CVC4, an SMT solver, which now includes optimization features. This enhancement represents a major leap forward, making CVC4 the first automated reasoning tool capable of performing synthesis and optimization simultaneously. Key accomplishments of this project include: The development of a new theoretical framework that unites synthesis with optimization, enabling more efficient and scalable system designs. The successful implementation of this framework within the CVC4 SMT solver, enhancing its capabilities and setting a new standard for automated reasoning tools. A comprehensive evaluation of the framework, including a case study for superconducting circuit design, demonstrating its practical application and effectiveness. These outcomes not only contribute to the theoretical foundations of computing but also provide tangible tools and frameworks that can be utilized in the design of emerging computing technologies.

The project has made substantial contributions beyond the academic and industrial communities. By enhancing CVC4 with optimization capabilities, it has made this tool more versatile and powerful, benefiting users worldwide. Furthermore, the project has played a significant role in educational and research infrastructure by: Training postdoctoral fellows and graduate students, equipping them with cutting-edge knowledge and skills. Contributing to the enhancement of CVC4, an open-source system, thus supporting a wide range of research and industrial applications.
